docs.snippet: THE Hurricane'' is an acclaimed motion picture. Denzel Washington, who portrays the wrongly convicted boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, won the Golden Globe for best actor in a drama and is expected to be nominated for an Academy Award; the movie mi...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Hurricane'' is an acclaimed motion picture. Denzel Washington, who portrays the wrongly convicted boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, won the Golden Globe for best actor in a drama and is expected to be nominated for an Academy Award; the movie might also be nominated for an Oscar. It's advertised as the ''most inspiring film of the year.'' It's just not the most truthful.
docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times article notes movie The Hurricane ignores key role played by New Jersey Public Defender's office investigator Fred Hogan in getting former boxer Rubin Carter's murder conviction overturned; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; One Man Carter Movie Ignored

docs.snippet: WE have come to expect a great deal of the Sundance Film Festival, the independent film world's annual gathering in the snowy, condo-packed valleys of the Wasatch Range. Besides offering a great confluence of buzz and celebrity, a career-advancing...
docs.lead_paragraph: WE have come to expect a great deal of the Sundance Film Festival, the independent film world's annual gathering in the snowy, condo-packed valleys of the Wasatch Range. Besides offering a great confluence of buzz and celebrity, a career-advancing opportunity for young filmmakers, a meat market for agents-on-the-make, a bazaar for indie-film distributors and a stage for artiste poseurs and hustler manques, it is also regarded as the year's prime opportunity to take the pulse of American independent filmmaking. ''I think it's probably as good a measure as any that's out there,'' said Robert Redford, the actor and Oscar-winning director whose Sundance Institute sponsors the festival, which ended its 10-day run here a week ago.

docs.snippet: Sarah Caudwell, the British author whose modest but ecstatically received output of three erudite and maliciously witty mystery novels led at least one critic to compare her to Oscar Wilde, died on Jan. 28 at her home in London. She was 60.    The...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sarah Caudwell, the British author whose modest but ecstatically received output of three erudite and maliciously witty mystery novels led at least one critic to compare her to Oscar Wilde, died on Jan. 28 at her home in London. She was 60. The cause was cancer, said Barney Karpfinger, her agent.

docs.snippet: Imagine an array of children's films and videos with plenty of folk tales (but no Disney), lots of Japanese animation (but no Pokemon) and many science-fiction quests (but no ''Star Wars'' sequels or prequels).    You would have the New York Inter...
docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine an array of children's films and videos with plenty of folk tales (but no Disney), lots of Japanese animation (but no Pokemon) and many science-fiction quests (but no ''Star Wars'' sequels or prequels). You would have the New York International Children's Film Festival, which opens this weekend. Now in its third year, the festival is devoted to the kind of fare that may be found at the Academy Awards but not at the local multiplex.
docs.abstract: Laurel Graeber Family Fare column discusses New York International Children's Film Festival at Cantor Film Center, Senegalese festival at Children's Museum of Arts, and exhibit of work of E W Godwin, 19th-century architect, decorator and designer, at Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts; photo (M)

docs.snippet: What's worse than having one of those hostile family Christmases ornamented with guilt, sibling rivalry and intergenerational tension -- the kind during which one person blows up and leaves the room in a huff, upsetting the children? Answer: Getti...
docs.lead_paragraph: What's worse than having one of those hostile family Christmases ornamented with guilt, sibling rivalry and intergenerational tension -- the kind during which one person blows up and leaves the room in a huff, upsetting the children? Answer: Getting a telephone call shortly afterward announcing that that person has commited suicide. James Coburn, as Atticus Cody, receives that honor in the CBS movie ''Missing Pieces.'' The volatile family member is Atticus's son Scott (Paul Kersey), a black sheep who is artistic and lives in Mexico. His situation is summed up by wildly inventive dialogue like ''He's wasting his life down there, you know'' (Atticus to his other son, a senator) and, ''I'm a painter, not a ranch hand'' (Scott to Atticus). Scott would probably have been a rebel anyway, but things are made worse by his mother's death 12 years ago in a horrible car accident. He was driving.
docs.abstract: Anita Gates reviews television programs Missing Pieces, on CBS, and The Others, on NBC; photo (M)

headline.main: TV Weekend; Poor Dad Seems Confused, And He's Not the Only One

docs.snippet: Theater    ''CHARLOTTE'S WEB.'' Theaterworks/USA presents E. B. White's classic tale of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider. In this hourlong production, with book by Joseph Robinette, Charlotte assures her friend Wilbur that she will save him...
docs.lead_paragraph: Theater ''CHARLOTTE'S WEB.'' Theaterworks/USA presents E. B. White's classic tale of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider. In this hourlong production, with book by Joseph Robinette, Charlotte assures her friend Wilbur that she will save him from the slaughterhouse. Auditorium at Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 52nd Street, tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 p.m. Tickets $19. Reservations: (212) 627-7373. ''THE DIARY OF ANNE FRANK,'' an adaptation of Anne Frank's diary for youngsters over the age of 8 who are able to understand the context of the play, by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett. Ronete Levenson has the title role. The New York Youth Theater, at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. Today at 7 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12. Reservations, (212) 888-0696.

docs.snippet: OSCAR WILDE is said to have defined an expert as an ordinary man away from home giving advice. Today, those words may be truer than ever, with a few tweaks. An expert, it seems, is now an ordinary person sitting at home, beaming advice over the In...
docs.lead_paragraph: OSCAR WILDE is said to have defined an expert as an ordinary man away from home giving advice. Today, those words may be truer than ever, with a few tweaks. An expert, it seems, is now an ordinary person sitting at home, beaming advice over the Internet to anyone who wants help. In the last few months, thousands of such ordinary people have signed up to wear the label of online expert. They are participating in a new breed of Web site that tries to match people who have questions with people who think they have answers.
docs.abstract: New breed of Web sites are springing up that try to match people who have questions with people who think they have answers; sites, known as expert sites or knowledge networks, are according to people who developed them, latest stage in Internet's evolution; examples of such sites are ExpertCentral (expertcentral.com) and KnowPost (knowpost,com); while dealing with real people who provide answers to a variety of questions can be very rewarding, it also means having to cope with people who have real desires to build reputations, or who, at the worst, have real delusions about whether they know what they are talking about; photos (M)

docs.snippet: The 10th season of Jazz at Lincoln Center, beginning in September, will embrace more than 450 events worldwide, including extended touring residencies by the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra in France, Italy, Germany, the Czech Republic and England. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The 10th season of Jazz at Lincoln Center, beginning in September, will embrace more than 450 events worldwide, including extended touring residencies by the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra in France, Italy, Germany, the Czech Republic and England. The schedule, announced yesterday by Rob Gibson, the organization's executive producer and director, will also include concerts and educational programs centering around Louis Armstrong's centennial year; an expansion of the annual Essentially Ellington High School Jazz Band Competition and Festival to include Canadian schools; and a number of concerts at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan featuring the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, reaffirming the connection between jazz and dancing.
docs.abstract: Schedule for 10th season of Jazz at Lincoln Center is announced (M)

headline.main: Lincoln Center Plans Busy Jazz Season
